title: 115_hr2094
content: The Act titled "Lead Free Schools Act of 2017" establishes requirements for regulating contaminants in schools. Section 1412(b)(2) of the Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to require the Administrator to issue revised national regulations for lead and copper within 9 months of the enactment of the Lead Free Schools Act of 2017. The revised regulations must ensure that corrosion controls are reevaluated whenever source water or treatment is changed. The Lead Free Schools Act of 2017 amends the Safe Drinking Water Act to require revised national regulations for lead and copper within 9 months. The regulations must ensure valid test results, monitoring of school sites, and clear notification of lead problems, including annual updates for schools. The Lead Free Schools Act of 2017 amends the Safe Drinking Water Act to require revised national regulations for lead and copper within 9 months. The regulations mandate valid test results, monitoring of school sites, and prompt replacement of lead service lines when contamination is detected, regardless of ownership. The Lead Free Schools Act of 2017 mandates the publication of a maximum contaminant level goal and regulation for perfluorinated compounds within 2 years. Additionally, a determination on regulating 1,4-dioxane must be made within the same timeframe. SEC. 3. DEFINITION OF LEAD SERVICE LINE. Amends the Safe Drinking Water Act to define a lead service line as a pipe and fittings that are not lead-free connecting the water main to a building inlet. Conforming amendment made to the Act. SEC. 4. COMPETITIVE GRANT PILOT PROGRAM FOR DRINKING WATER FOUNTAIN REPLACEMENT FOR SCHOOLS. Introduces a competitive grant pilot program for replacing drinking water fountains in schools. The Administrator will establish a grant program to replace old drinking water fountains in schools. Funds will cover replacement costs and will be awarded competitively. Up to $5,000,000 is authorized annually for this program. SEC. 5. SCHOOL REMEDIAL ACTION PROGRAM. Amends the Safe Drinking Water Act to increase funding to $100,000,000 annually from 2018 through 2022 for replacing old drinking water fountains in schools.
